[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION
(Compensations and Insurance Premiums)


    1. Dr Chau Sik Ting asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour what was the total amount of premium collected under the Workmen's Compensation Act for each of the years 1976 to 1980, and what was the total amount of

Column: 934

compensation paid out in each of those years.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the Insurance Commissioner's Department of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, the gross premiums collected by insurance companies for workmen's compensation over the period from 1976 to 1980 were as follows:

Column: 935 

    Workmen's Compensation Premium

                      ($ million)
      1976                51.3
      1977                48.9
      1978                53.0
      1979                59.1
      1980                68.7 (estimated)


    The amounts of compensation paid out for these years are as follows: 
    Workmen's Compensation Paid Out

                      ($ million)
      1976                12.9
      1977                18.5
      1978                15.8
      1979                16.5
      1980                17.6


     Dr Chau Sik Ting (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the substantial profits accrued to the insurance industry from the implementation of the Workmen's Compensation Act, could not a certain proportion of this enormous profit be ploughed back to help promote occupational safety and health to prevent further injuries and disability?

    It is important to place a certain amount of social responsibility publicly on the insurance industry to contribute towards the preservation of worker's lives and limbs rather than just raking in profits. All preventive measures will help reduce industrial accidents and diseases which, in turn, will help reduce the amount of compensation paid out, thus benefiting the insurance industry.

    Could the Hon. Minister not take concrete steps to ensure that the insurance industry make such a contribution? For example, the Hon. Minister can take measures to influence the insurance industry to form their own environmental and health inspectorate to ensure that the insured companies maintain at least statutory standards of industrial safety and health in their premises.

     Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad that the Member has noticed that workmen's compensation is indeed a very lucrative branch of the insurance business. However, the Member would not have the

Column: 936

privilege or rather opportunity to raise this question prior to 1975. The Insurance Commissioner's report then did not classify workmen's compensation under a separate column. It was lumped under "Miscellaneous". I suspected then that a large amount of the money in the Miscellaneous accounts must have come from the workmen's compensation insurance. As a result of the intervention of the Ministry of Labour, the Commissioner of Insurance had, since 1976, reclassified workmen's compensation as a branch by itself and from that year we were able to compare the figures.

    On 1st October, 1975, we implemented the new rates for workmen's compensation, resulting in an increase in the quantum of compensation and a concomitant increase in premium. The insurance industry raised the premium by about 100%. The Ministry of Labour again intervened and we managed to cut down the increase in premium to 50%. Even then I thought that the rates were high. But the Workmen's Compensation Act is a piece of social legislation in that not only does it protect the workers, it in fact legislates for the insurance companies. Not only do we legislate for the business but we also enforce it, we make sure that they get the business by penalizing those employers who fail to take up insurance for their workers. We have enforcement measures under the Factories Act to cut down the number of accidents so that with less claims we again ensure that there is a profit margin.

    The Member for Thomson is absolutely right in his call for the insurance companies to be more active in the area of workers' protection rather than be the most passive party by writing out insurance policies. The Government does the legislation and enforcement. The insurance companies just write out policies. But there has been a change of heart since. The hon. Member for Jalan Kayu is not here today but, since he took an active part in the General Insurance Association, there has been a very close contact between the Association and the Ministry of Labour. In fact, the Association has offered to donate at least a quarter of a million dollars and they are also considering a

Column: 937

yearly donation thereafter to help out in areas of accident prevention.

    I assure the hon. Member that the Ministry of Labour will not stop just here. It will continue to liaise with the insurance companies to make sure that some of the profits will be ploughed back to the workers.

     Encik Abbas Abu Amin (Pasir Panjang): Sir, I would like to seek some clarification on the number of times the Workmen's Compensation Act has been reviewed. Are there any provisions made for the rehabilitation of workers who are unable to continue with their normal work due to accident or other mishaps?

     Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, there is a periodic, but not regular, review of the amounts of compensation to be paid to the injured workman or his next-of-kin if he dies in an accident. In the revision, we take into consideration the rise in the cost of living, the inflation factor, so that the deceased worker's family or he himself, if he is only maimed, will not suffer any anxiety or hardship in his livelihood, at least for a short period of time. There is a constant review and, at the appropriate time, the quantum will be increased.

    As to the question of rehabilitative training, that is another aspect of the Ministry's work. There is really no institutionalized training as such, if that is what the Member has in mind. In fact, the NTUC was thinking of establishing rehabilitative training under the Labour Foundation. They are having second thoughts about this. We in the Ministry of Labour have had a very queer experience, i.e. very few of the injured workers are prepared to undergo rehabilitative training. They would rather approach Members of Parliament for a hawker stall, which is an easier and more profitable occupation. So we have been quite unsuccessful in getting enough numbers of these people to undergo rehabilitative training.

    Under the Employment Service, there is a small section which does rehabilitative training. Unfortunately, again, only a small

Column: 938

number of workers who sustained injuries as a result of accidents are undergoing rehabilitative training. Most of these people being trained are really those who were born handicapped either in their limbs or in their vision. No institutionalized training is necessary for the time being because the number is so small.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, it is heartening to note that the General Insurance Association has agreed to give a contribution, which was a point raised by the Member for Thomson. First, does the Minister or the Senior Parliamentary Secretary consider that a contribution of a quarter million dollars is a token or an initial amount, and whether in his opinion it is a reasonable amount? Secondly, would it fall under the purview of the Ministry to ensure that claims for compensation are cleared or settled with expedition, because I have received complaints from my constituents that their claims for compensation have been prolonged. There have been instances, however, when the delays have been due to the lack of consensus between the parties involved. I would like the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to assure me that in cases where there have been undue delays, will the Ministry take the responsibility to ensure that such cases can be expedited.

     Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, the relationship between the Ministry of Labour and the General Insurance Association has, in fact, developed into something more than a mere dialogue. We intend to involve the General Insurance Association in our future work, like accident prevention for the workers. There is an indication that the Association is now more responsive to our call, and I have no reason at this moment to suspect their sincerity.

    As to the question of delay in the assessment, it is true that a number of cases have been delayed. However, not all cases are due to disagreement in the assessment but rather to the medical reports. The Member for Kampong Kembangan will appreciate that we, in the Ministry of Labour, are all laymen and we have to depend on the medical

Column: 939

report. Sometimes, say, in the case of a complicated injury, the doctor is not able to fix a quantum on the degree of disability. It may take some months to assess the degree of permanent disability and no doctor will pen a medical report declaring a certain percentage of disability without a thorough examination of the patient to see how he responds to physiotherapy treatment. It is only after such treatment that the doctor can be certain of the degree of disability. The delay is mainly due to this aspect of the work.

    However, there is provision for an award of interim payment. We will see to it that the worker does get something in the meantime. But it is important for an injured worker to comply with the doctor's appointment, because if he were to ignore continued medical examination or surveillance he might aggravate his injury and complicate matters. So it is a matter of medical assessment. The Ministry has no alternative but to depend on the doctor's final medical report before we can finalize the case.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, in view of the obscenely large profits made by the insurance companies either as a group or individually, will the Senior Parliamentary Secretary make another attempt to persuade the General Insurance Association to contribute at least half a million dollars annually?

     Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, Parliament is in no position to compel people to part with their money. I am sorry if I have missed out the point raised by the Member for Kampong Kembangan. He has asked whether a quarter of a million dollars is a token sum. As I have said, we will continue to work together with the Association. We expect more help from them.

    I do not know how one can describe "profit" as obscene. It is just like describing people who are filthy rich, out of jealousy more than anything else. Previously, when the statistics were not included in the Commissioner's report, the insurance companies turned round and said, "Mr Fong, we are in the dark and we do not know how much we have paid out." We told them that if they were in the dark, then they should not be in

Column: 940

this branch of the business. They did not keep statistics because they knew that they were making good profits. When they do keep statistics, it is to prove to the Government that they are not doing well, and they say, "Please help us to increase."

    As a result of our intervention, as I have said, we managed to get the statistics and they try to use this surplus to cover the other branches of the insurance business, overheads, and so on. It is not for us to demand a fixed sum from them, but there is nothing wrong for them to search their conscience to give us a bit more.

Column: 940

INSTITUTE OF OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
(Comparative study)


    2. Dr Chau Sik Ting asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour when the comparative study of the Institute of Occupational Safety and Health commenced; when it will be completed and when it will be made public.

     Mr Fong Sip Chee (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Sir, the proposed functions of the Institute of Occupational Safety and Health are training, consultancy and research in industrial safety and health. A study of how such functions are discharged in some developed and developing countries started in April 1980. The study is to ascertain whether institutes or other arrangements were resorted to and their success or failure. The industrial safety situation of certain countries will also be examined. The study is expected to be completed by May this year.

    Since the study is an internal one designed to enable the Ministry to decide on whether it should establish the institute in the way that it was originally formulated or resort to other arrangements, it is therefore not proposed to make public the findings. It is not necessary.

     Dr Chau Sik Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary told this House in 1978 that the green light was given

Column: 941

to set up the proposed Institute of Occupational Safety and Health. In fact, it was budgeted for FY 80 and FY 81. A proper study must have been made. And I accept his explanation on the purpose of this present study.

    The Japanese Government set up such an Institute soon after the war, and it has contributed significantly to their much lower industrial accident rate. Concern for the safety and health of our workers is an important area. We must learn from the Japanese as well as the West. It will mean greater productivity in the long run. However, if we drag our feet further, our workers will continue to lose their lives and limbs. Could the Senior Parliamentary Secretary not accelerate the introduction of the necessary legislation for the establishment of this Institute?

     Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, first, I have not the slightest intention to be drawn into the same controversy as the debate on police stations which occurred yesterday. Otherwise I will get an open invitation to join that side of the House!

    That is not the case, neither it is the intention. The need for the institute has been established. But we are studying into the size, the detailed functions and all the aspects as to what is the best form it should take.

    There are good points in the Japanese example but there are also some frightening aspects. For instance, the amount of money they spend to feed rabbits for their research in that institute is about three-quarters of the entire budget for our Factory Inspectorate. This is just for feeding rabbits alone. We have to feed our engineers in the Factory Inspectorate. It is the size of the project, the extent of commitment that we do not want to leap into. So before we plunge into this project and decide on the scope or functions of the Institute, it is prudent for us to look further. It may not take the form of an institute. The name was given for want of a better one or for want of a better arrangement. It may be a society. It may be a board. But there is a need

Column: 942

for us to go into these areas of consultancy, research and training as we become more and more industrialized.

    I assure the Member that the subject is moving very much in the Ministry. I assure the House that there is no delay in the way that the police stations have suffered from the Ministry of Finance.

Column: 942

CAR-PARKING IN HOUSING BOARD ESTATES


    3. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board can set aside some parking lots in the seasonal car parks for visitors, who otherwise would have to find a coupon parking area some distance away, and also introduce a system whereby a visitor who has to make a short call can be given a slip permitting him free parking for five to ten minutes, obviating the need for him to display a parking coupon.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the introduction of coupon parking in November 1980, the HDB has been converting its season car parks to include short-term parking as well. This conversion is being implemented in stages.

    The HDB has always been granting motorists five minutes of free parking. In the past, motorists who needed to make short calls were given advice slips by parking attendants, permitting them free parking for five minutes. With the implementation of coupon parking, the five minutes' grace period is still being given to motorists. HDB enforcement officers making their rounds will take note of vehicles without coupons and allow them five minutes free parking before issuing notices.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, I wonder whether five minutes is sufficient for a driver to park his car at a parking lot, wait for the lift to go up to one of the floors, and then finally comes down. When he comes down, of course, he finds that he has already got a notice on his car for parking without a parking coupon. I think this is not fair to the

Column: 943

motorists. I wonder whether the Hon. Minister could persuade the HDB parking authorities to have more attendants around to issue these notices to extend the grace period from five minutes to 10, or maybe 15 minutes.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, if we have to employ more parking attendants, this would defeat the purpose of coupon parking. The five-minute grace period is for those who need only five minutes, for example, to go into the car park to drop somebody or to pick up someone. But if the person needs to go into the flat and spend a few minutes to attend to his business or wait for somebody, then in that case he will have to pay for the parking.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I just come back to season car parking ticket? For HDB residents who have got parents living in HDB flats in other HDB housing estates, can we not give them the privilege of using their season car parking ticket in other housing estates? This will probably save the cost of printing so many parking coupons. I wonder how much the Minister spends in printing these coupons.

    The other question is whether the Minister could give people a chance to use coupons if they find that it is too costly to use the season ticket? As for me, I do not use the season ticket. But if I have to go to car parks that require it, then I can use coupons. Maybe my case is not a good example, but other people may need the opportunity to use coupons.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, our present system allows those who require long-term parking to buy monthly parking tickets. For those who require short-term parking, they can use coupons. I think this is a more satisfactory arrangement. Let them decide for themselves which system suits them best. If they find that they have to visit the place very often, then they may opt to pay $15 for a monthly parking ticket. If they have to visit the place only for a short while at irregular intervals, then in that case it is cheaper for them to use coupons.

Column: 944



     Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Sir, will the Hon. Minister consider allowing season parking ticket holders to opt for an alternative? In other words, they are prepared to pay over and above the $15 for a season ticket that can be used in other HDB estates as well. This will probably alleviate the problems of families visiting one another.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: In this case, I would advise them to use coupons.

     Mr Rohan bin Kamis (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, in order to encourage closer family ties, could the Minister consider asking the HDB to charge a flat rate for parking on a per entry basis for its car parks during Sundays and public holidays?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think this problem has been looked into. We have found that this is not advisable because if we allow parking on a per entry basis, then what we are afraid of is that on Sundays people might leave their cars for the whole day. If it is on a per entry basis, the charge cannot be too high. So they leave their cars in the car park the whole of Sunday and they may even go somewhere else, to the pictures or visit friends. Then we may have a situation where the season car parking ticket holders come back and find that all the parking lots are full and they cannot get in. Or other casual visitors may come to visit friends and they may find that all the parking lots have been taken up.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am suggesting here that the parking authorities introduce certain visitors' parking lots for people who are there on short visits. If these visitors' parking lots are introduced, motorists can park at these lots for short calls and perhaps the enforcement officers could keep an eye on just these visitors' parking lots so that any vehicle found parked longer than five or 10 minutes, they can then issue a notice.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I think I have answered that question. We allow people a five-minute grace period and if they park longer than five minutes they will get a notice. And those who park for less than five minutes, no notice will be issued to them.

Column: 945

Usually the enforcement officers do not strictly adhere to the five minutes grace period. For example, if a person parks his car at a car park and the enforcement officer is not around, he may park for 10 or 15 minutes. When the enforcement officer comes round, he looks at that particular vehicle which is without a coupon and he allows a five-minute grace period before he issues a ticket. Quite often, the car may be parked there for 25 minutes and then a ticket is issued.

Column: 945

LOW WATER PRESSURE IN HOUSING BOARD FLATS


    4. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development what remedial action the Housing and Development Board can take to increase water pressure for residents living in the upper floors, as the present low water pressure causes them considerable inconvenience.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board will be taking steps to improve the water pressure at the top two floors of existing high-rise flats where the pressure is low. Additional mains and separate down-feed pipes for the top two floors will be installed. Work will commence in mid-1981 and will be completed by 1983.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, this problem of low water pressure has been discovered not very long ago. Since the Hon. Minister for National Development has said that the HDB is going to rectify this defect, I hope the Minister can assure this House that steps will be taken as quickly as possible to relieve this problem of low water pressure faced by the residents, especially those who live in the upper floors of the various housing blocks.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the number of high-rise blocks involved is very large. We are carrying out the work in stages. According to the HDB programme, by 1983 this problem of low water pressure at the top two floors in

Column: 946

high-rise flats will be rectified. I am sorry to say that the other flat dwellers will still have to put up with low water pressure for a while.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: If that is the case, it does show that in the planning stage of the building of the blocks, vis-a-vis the water tanks and the piping, etc., there has been a defect in planning. So I would like to seek the assurance of the Hon. Minister for National Development that when the new towns are being planned this problem will not arise. I have in mind the Hou Gang New Town which will have 26,000 units. In the Punggol Housing Estate, which was built some seven years ago, I have a lot of complaints about low water pressure. Therefore, in the planning of the new towns, not only Hou Gang, but anywhere else, would there be adequate provision to ensure that the water pressure will not be low as to cause inconvenience to the residents?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I can give the Member for Punggol the assurance that in the building of new flats this problem will be avoided.

Column: 946

ANTI-SOCIAL PRACTICES IN
HOUSING BOARD ESTATES


    5. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development what the Housing and Development Board proposes to do to solve the problem of dirty lifts, as practically every lift in the Board's estates is being soiled by people who relieve themselves in it.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board takes a very serious view of offences like urinating in the lifts. Except for very young children and those of unsound mind, the HDB will prosecute and evict persons caught relieving themselves in the lifts, even if the culprit is not living in the same estate.

    Complete eradication of such anti-social habits requires education of residents. I would like to urge all Residents' Committees to plan education programmes and campaigns against this anti-social behaviour. In

Column: 947

the estates where there are such programmes, there has been a noticeable decrease of such complaints.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (River Valley): With Your permission, Sir, I would like to expand on this point about littering in lifts as well as littering outside lifts. As we all know, there is a certain amount of throwing of rubbish from the upper floors of HDB estates. Recently a woman was injured when a tin of water fell on her head. Fortunately she did not die.

    In my visits to HDB estates in my constituency this complaint of residents thoughtlessly throwing things down from their flats, thus dirtying clothes that are hung out to dry, has become fairly frequent.

     Mr Speaker: Dr Tay, will you phrase your point as a supplementary question, rather than going into a debate?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Yes, Sir. The question I want to ask is: can the HDB increase the fine, which I understand at present is only $500, so as to make this offence more serious, and also to deter people from such unsocial acts?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I think we may have to change the law if we want to increase the fine. Under the Environmental Public Health Act the maximum fine is $500 for throwing rubbish or littering. So to increase the fine, we have to amend the law.

     Dr Wan Soon Bee (West Coast): Sir, the question of anti-social behaviour is one of the problems. The other problem is that there are no toilets in the void decks. I wonder if the Minister will consider building some toilets in the void decks?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: I think the same request was raised by the Member for Radin Mas yesterday in this House. To build a toilet in every void deck is very costly and it is also very costly to maintain. At present HDB is building kiosks with toilets in some of the void decks where a small kiosk is provided for the selling of newspapers and sweets. Though these toilets are not available in every block, they can be found in several places. I hope the provision of this facility will reduce this anti-social habit.

Column: 948



     Mr Rohan bin Kamis: Sir, it is heartening to hear that the Hon. Minister will evict any residents of HDB flats who relieve themselves in the lift. What would the ruling be if it is found that the residents' pets have been urinating in the lifts? Is he going to consider evicting the pets?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: We will look into the circumstances. Most probably the owner will not be allowed to keep the pet, as it shows that the owner is not able to properly look after his pet.

Column: 948

TRAFFIC CONGESTION ALONG
UPPER THOMSON CORRIDOR


    6. Dr Chau Sik Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether his Ministry has plans to relieve the traffic congestion during peak hours at the junctions of Lornie/Thomson Roads and Upper Thomson/Braddell Roads which is expected to worsen with the development of Ang Mo Kio and Yishun New Towns.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the traffic congestion at the junctions of Lornie Road/Thomson Road and Upper Thomson Road/Braddell Road has been relieved since October 1979 by the opening of Marymount Road between Avenue 1 Ang Mo Kio and Thomson Road.

    With the continuing development of Ang Mo Kio and Yishun New Towns, the travel demand along the Upper Thomson/Sembawang corridor will rise. To meet this demand, the Public Works Department will be constructing two Expressways, the Sembawang Expressway and the Central Expressway, linking Ang Mo Kio in the North to the Bukit Timah one-way pair in the South via the Keng Lee Road/Kampong Java Road one-way system.

    Tenders for the Sembawang Expressway from Avenue 1, Ang Mo Kio to Jalan Toa Payoh will be invited in April 1981. Work will be completed by the end of 1982. Construction of the Central Expressway from Jalan Toa Payoh to Thomson Road is scheduled to commence in early 1982 and completed by the end of 1984.

Column: 949



    These Expressways, together with other major arterial roads in the area, will be adequate to cater for the projected travel demand between Upper Thomson/Sembawang corridor and the City.

     Dr Chau Sik Ting: Sir, for 15 years or more, residents of the Thomson Constituency have been inconvenienced by recurrent road-work connected with road-widening programmes and change of traffic system.
